<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskExit:
```c
void OS_TaskExit()
{
    osal_id_t         task_id;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
    }

    /* call the implementation */
    OS_TaskExit_Impl();

    /* Impl function never returns */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment. Passing &token hands the address of a local object to OS_TaskDetach_Impl; modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted. Rule 17.8 would be violated only if OS_TaskDetach_Impl modified its pointer parameter itself (for example: void OS_TaskDetach_Impl(OS_object_token_t *token_ptr) { token_ptr = NULL; } or token_ptr = some_other_address; ), but there is no evidence of that here.
